text.headline: Historic Images of Deary Timeline
text.text: Historic photos of people, places, and events from Deary's founding to the twenty century.

text.headline: Deary in winter

text.headline: Panorama of Deary
text.text: Deary about 1911, looking northwest from a point not far from the school.  The McQueary Hotel hides part of the west side of Main Street.  Above it are the hardware and the drug store, both characterized by false fronts with peaks.  The flat roof between is part of the drug store.  Next is the box-like shape of the bank.  Up the street, partly hidden, is a larger building that at this time or later housed the Olson store, and over it is seen the roof of the depot.  The largest building on the east side of the street, the one with many windows, is the Carlson Hotel.  Above it, just below the railroad crossing, is the newspaper office.  (Description from the book, The Trees Grew Tall, by John B. Miller)

text.headline: Main Street in Deary
text.text: Deary about 1909, looking north across the main road, which is now the highway.  The first building on the left is the Don Sahlin Saloon.  Beyond the corner, with a false front facing east and a gable at rear facing south, is the Bill Smith store.  The buildings above are not seen clearly, but the peaked roofs of both the hardware and drug store can be distinguished, and the bank certainly existed.  Farther up and to the left is the railway station, and well beyond it the Hugh Henry house.  Buildings on the east (right) side of the street include the McQueary Hotel, the harness shop, and the Carlson Hotel.  In the right-hand section beyond the tracks is the McGown home.  (Descrption from the book, The Trees Grew Tall, by John B. Miller)

text.headline: Main Street and Post Office
text.text: Main Street and Post Office in Deary, with flag flying and cars parked along the street.

media.caption: Children in parade on Main Street

text.headline: Children in parade on Main Street
text.text: School children in a parade at Fair time (note carousel in background) in Deary.

media.caption: Main Street of Deary with cars full of people

text.headline: Main Street of Deary with cars full of people
text.text: Deary Main Street with some event taking place.  People are on the board sidewalk and six cars are packed with people for either a parade or race!  On the left, are the pool hall, post office, Peterson building (Albert Pierce store), and a building (previously the Olson store) which at this date housed the barber shop and Dr. Faust's office.  The large building above the bank was, at this time, occupied either by Olson or Sam Anderson. The forward three cars of the line-up are a Reo, owned by Jorgeson, a Winton owned by Drury, and a Studebaker.

text.headline: Main Street of Deary after fire
text.text: Main Street, Deary, after the fire in 1923, showing rubble, four men, broken sidewalk, and the Farmers Warehouse and Elevator Company elevator.

text.headline: Burkland Mill
text.text: Burkland Mill near Deary

text.headline: Horse logging
text.text: Joe Wells horse logging crew near Deary.  Men on the logpile are Joe, Roy and Chuck Wells.  Man on right is unidentified.  Joe had been born a slave in 1958, and was freed by the Civil War.  The Wells brothers took him as their ward and treated him like a brother.  Joe loved them equally, and took their surname.  When the Wells came West, Joe and his young wife came along.  His wife was named Lou, and their sons were Chuck and Roy, and daughter was Mary (Wells) King.

text.headline: O. E. Mang, blacksmith
text.text: Men and horses outside the blacksmith shop of O. E. Mang. Two houses are in the background.

text.headline: Pool Hall
text.text: Pool hall in Deary, including an old radio (Victrola?) on a counter and display cases containing cigar boxes and other items.  Two pans on the floor may have been used as spitoons or ash receptacles.  There is a man behind the counter and five men posing in the hall.

text.headline: Emery Olson Co. General Merchandise
text.text: Two men on the porch in front of the Emory Olson Co. General Merchandise store in Deary.  Below a window is a sign advertising cream separators.

text.headline: Depot
text.text: Deary Depot, with people standing on the platform, along with a wagon and two milk cans.

text.headline: W.I & M. Depot
text.text: Washington, Idaho & Montana (W.I.&M) Railroad Depot, locomotive and train in Deary.

text.headline: Lee's Garage
text.text: Esten Lee's garage in Deary with three men behind the counter. Left to right - Andrew Carlson, Esten Lee, Jack Brown.  Automobile tires are stored overhead.  A sign on the wall reads "Cash Makes No Enemies."

text.headline: Alex's Mexican-American Food
text.text: Deary, Alex's Cafe, formerly blacksmith's shop. A car and a truck are in front of the business.

text.headline: U.S. Post Office
text.text: Former building of the Latah County State Bank in Deary, Idaho. Photographed site of the United States Postal Office in Deary, Idaho 83823. This photograph is the head-on image of the building

text.headline: United States Post Office
text.text: Former building of the Latah County State Bank in Deary, Idaho. Photographed site of the United States Postal Office in Deary, Idaho 83823. This diagonal view photograph was taken for the County Historical Site Survey.

text.headline: Latah County State Bank
text.text: Latah County State Bank, Deary Idaho. Brick building with dirt roads around it. A boardwalk can be seen in front. This was the only building on this block to survive the fire of October of 1923.

text.headline: Deary Library
text.text: Interior of the new library in Deary, Idaho. This photogrpah was taken in conjunction with the new library opening in 1988.

text.headline: Anton Lee home
text.text: Anton Lee home in Deary, with photo studio upstairs.  Four men are posing, hats are on the ground, all are holding either rifles or some type of tool.  Pick axes and bags are on the ground.

text.text: Deary School.  The lower floor was constructed in 1908, the upper in 1911.  Two outbuildings appear behind the school.

text.headline: Chris Peterson, Woodcutter
text.text: Chris Peterson, Deary woodcutter, driving a motorized saw.

text.headline: Deary Quilters
text.text: Deary quilters group, the women who made a friendship quilt for Sam and Belle Sturman when the couple moved away in 1939. Includes Mrs. Clarence Sturman (Goldie), Mrs Sam Sturman, (Belle), Mrs John Sturman (Rose), Mrs Carl Johnson, Mrs. Drury, Mrs Louis Hansen (Amanda), Mrs Slocum, Ellie Miller, Bertha Alber, Viola Baker, Laura Femerite, Estelle Darr.

text.headline: Avon Busy Bees
text.text: The Avon Busy Bees, a ladies' social club which met in the Avon Church, the only major building left in town. The Avon Busy Bees was originally formed in 1920 and were still meeting in 1999.  Four of the women are identified:  Marilyn Osterberg in blue top, center; Marie Hatke, in pink shirt to right of Marilyn; Grace Elliott in sunglasses next to Marie; Lynn Martin, next to Grace.

text.headline: Threshing grain
text.text: A grain threshing scene, showing a thresher/grain separator, straw stacks, sacked grain, and threshing crew of eleven.  William Asplund's outfit.

media.caption: Steam thresher crew and cook wagon

text.headline: Steam thresher crew and cook wagon
text.text: Harvest scene, showing steam engine and belt, cookwagon, horses, stacks of straw, steam thresher crew, and straw stackers (?) in the background.

text.headline: Cut-over land
text.text: Cut-over land, as left by logger - selling for $20 per acre.
